greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Smallest powerful number (definition 1) such that a(n)+n is also powerful.
comment: McDaniel proved that a(n) exists for all n > 0.
Sister sequence of a(n)+n given by A103952.
reference: R. K. Guy, Unsolved Problems in Number Theory, B16
link: Donovan Johnson, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..109
Wayne L. McDaniel, Representations of every integer as the difference of powerful numbers, Fibonacci Quarterly 20 (1982), pp. 85-87.
Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, Powerful numbers
example: 214369=463^2 and 214375=5^4*7^3 are the smallest pair of powerful numbers differing by 6, so a(6)=214369.
results.author: _Jud McCranie_, Oct 13 2002
